text: Good morning everyone, I am backtesting a strategy and obtained this profit plot. Do you think this indicates the value opportunity was there but it disappeared when profit goes "flat"? This is ~900 markets, ~2200 orders

elements.text: Good morning everyone, I am backtesting a strategy and obtained this profit plot. Do you think this indicates the value opportunity was there but it disappeared when profit goes "flat"? This is ~900 markets, ~2200 orders

text: Sample size probably too small to give up on it but yeah this is definitely not what you want to see from the cumulative profit plot

elements.text: Sample size probably too small to give up on it but yeah this is definitely not what you want to see from the cumulative profit plot

text: thanks Mo!

elements.text: thanks Mo!

text: This will depend on number of events, average odds, staking, etc. etc. but speaking very generally, it's entirely feasible for a strategy to be flat for a quarter

elements.text: This will depend on number of events, average odds, staking, etc. etc. but speaking very generally, it's entirely feasible for a strategy to be flat for a quarter

text: I think conventional wisdom is also that the edge would gradually erode rather than disappearing overnight

elements.text: I think conventional wisdom is also that the edge would gradually erode rather than disappearing overnight

text: But it's very good practice to always look at the cumulative return plot as it gives you a much more nuanced feel for the strategy than headline numbers

elements.text: But it's very good practice to always look at the cumulative return plot as it gives you a much more nuanced feel for the strategy than headline numbers

text: got it, thanks for the insights Mo, appreciate it a lot!

elements.text: got it, thanks for the insights Mo, appreciate it a lot!

text: Looks like if it weren't for a few longshots you'd be flat overall, no?

elements.text: Looks like if it weren't for a few longshots you'd be flat overall, no?

text: I wouldn't run it. You're less likely to get fully filled on those winning longshots, more likely to get fully filled on the losing bets

elements.text: I wouldn't run it. You're less likely to get fully filled on those winning longshots, more likely to get fully filled on the losing bets

text: yes thats a good point as well

elements.text: yes thats a good point as well

text: :smile: at some point we will all want to know what fixed it.

elements.text: at some point we will all want to know what fixed it.

text: one intersting point, would it make sense to keep only the backs, and be "done" with it?

elements.text: one intersting point, would it make sense to keep only the backs, and be "done" with it?

text:
To be clear I am live trading the strategy just backing

Whether to just move on is an interesting question of how to prioritise the infinite possibilities of what to work on. And perhaps more importantly, whether trying to solve the mystery of the poor laying performance is mainly just an intellectual exercise rather than a profitable one

elements.text:
To be clear I am live trading the strategy just backing

Whether to just move on is an interesting question of how to prioritise the infinite possibilities of what to work on. And perhaps more importantly, whether trying to solve the mystery of the poor laying performance is mainly just an intellectual exercise rather than a profitable one

text: Indeed, maybe if you fix the laying it backs even better :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Indeed, maybe if you fix the laying it backs even better

text: Out of curiosity, do your lays cluster in a smaller number of races? If you sample one bet per race in a MC sim, how does this look on PNL? Perhaps when you're miscalibrated and missing a factor, you're laying a lot

elements.text: Out of curiosity, do your lays cluster in a smaller number of races? If you sample one bet per race in a MC sim, how does this look on PNL? Perhaps when you're miscalibrated and missing a factor, you're laying a lot

text: Another thing to look at here from the 'are the prices I'm taking any good?' line is to check the average size of the levels you're trying to take liquidity from on back vs lay in your model. Need to be careful to to compare in the same price buckets since shown sizes vary so much with the price, but worth looking at

elements.text: Another thing to look at here from the 'are the prices I'm taking any good?' line is to check the average size of the levels you're trying to take liquidity from on back vs lay in your model. Need to be careful to to compare in the same price buckets since shown sizes vary so much with the price, but worth looking at

text:
I have a similar graph for a live dogs strategy that goes up steeply, then goes flat for a few weeks and then goes up again. So I'd say it _might_ be a goer but you'll need a bigger sample size (i.e. 6+ months).
Just noticed your graph covers 4 months, so I'd say that 2200 bets in that time period is nowhere near enough.

elements.text: I have a similar graph for a live dogs strategy that goes up steeply, then goes flat for a few weeks and then goes up again. So I'd say it
might

be a goer but you'll need a bigger sample size (i.e. 6+ months).

text: Do you get a similar shape with random datasets <@U011VL3CA2Y>? (although it's smallish already) But even breakeven strategies are well worth having so it's probably worth a bit more of your time.

elements.text: Do you get a similar shape with random datasets
? (although it's smallish already) But even breakeven strategies are well worth having so it's probably worth a bit more of your time.

text: Agree with <@UEA14GBRR>. Break even strategies are worthwhile for keeping your commission up, although most of my "break even" strategies ended up making a profit. :grinning:

elements.text: Agree with
. Break even strategies are worthwhile for keeping your commission up, although most of my "break even" strategies ended up making a profit.

text: <@UEA14GBRR> do you mean generating random subsamples with something like bootstrap?

elements.text: do you mean generating random subsamples with something like bootstrap?

text: good to know that break even strategies can also be valuable

elements.text: good to know that break even strategies can also be valuable

text: Yes, but I've no idea what bootstrap is.

elements.text: Yes, but I've no idea what bootstrap is.

text: fancy word for sampling with replacement :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:

elements.text: fancy word for sampling with replacement

text: Keep your eye on the future <@U011VL3CA2Y>,  Building that commission paid ratio as early as possible can save a lot of costs later.  Its like tax planning for your business.

elements.text: Keep your eye on the future
,  Building that commission paid ratio as early as possible can save a lot of costs later.  Its like tax planning for your business.

i'll keep that in mind

text: Thanks for the definition <@U011VL3CA2Y>.  I'm just a simple guy who doesn't keep up with the latest lingo. It's usually a case of the Emperor's new clothes anyway :wink:

text: I wish.   New tech feeds my habitual procrastination so I avoid it and keep it simple, then I avoid that too :grin:
